First, bodhisattvas give rise to this resolve:
Alas!

The bodies of all sentient beings in the world are afflicted with illness, with the four snakes stirring up their poisonous fangs to harm each other, accumulating suffering and creating many faults, with boils, sores, rashes, wind, bile, and phlegm, giving rise to various illnesses such as eye diseases, enduring much hardship and extreme harm, quickly decaying and impermanent, weak and decrepit, quickly approaching death, abandoned in the forest with nothing enjoyable.

Each giving rise to much anger and harm, widely producing great illness and distress in the body.
Diseases arise in the two places of the eyes and ears, and diseases also arise in the nose and tongue,
Diseases arise in the lips and teeth, and other illnesses arise all over the body,
Boils and sores first arise, producing pain and suffering, scabs and rashes then arise, the pain increasing greatly,
Other illnesses arise through many avenues, thus encircling the body.
Since this body gives rise to illnesses and afflictions, the accumulation of suffering is in its body,
Meaningless, unbeneficial, and harmful, quickly dissipating and perishing, the body perishes,
Once abandoned in the forest, what is there? Impermanent, swift, and not solid.
Contemplate carefully this foul-smelling body, which serves as a basis for various illnesses and suffering,
One should cultivate virtuous deeds, which will become the cause for attaining a Buddha's body in the future.
Abandoning such a multitude of evil bodies, which are broken, decayed, and fleeting,
The Buddha's body is accomplished with perfect virtues, an inconceivable great Dharma body.
Looking back at such a multitude of suffering bodies, with afflictions increasing everywhere, it is not enjoyable.

Alas! What is this body's pleasure?

I have given rise to laziness and inferior diligence, and have been ignorant, exhausted, without patience or love, and without any virtuous characteristics at all. Alas! All sentient beings in the world are unable to contemplate that all living beings have the same flesh and body, whether they exist or perish, their flesh is no different.

Those who eat it consider it to be without sin, and also without the appearance of sin, they consider it to be without merit, and also without the appearance of merit. Even to the farthest reaches of the ocean shore, all sentient beings see it no differently, without sin or merit.
For this reason, whether it is sin or merit, they are unable to understand.
Because of not knowing, they approach evil views and increase the darkness of delusion, not knowing the right path but only creating sinful karma.

Because of extensively creating unwholesome karma, when the fruits ripen, they attain an inferior physical appearance, and even fall into the hells and experience the suffering of the hells, swallowing hot iron balls, being tortured and beaten, bound and suspended, and brought to the brink of death, only to be revived by karma.
For many thousands of years they do not hear pleasant sounds, let alone pleasant touch.
This is because they do not know about sin and merit, and do not create the causes for giving. The wise should remember this.

I now arouse this mind and draw close to good friends. I will obtain a human body, not sparing my body or life, extensively practicing giving and creating all kinds of good karma. I will draw close to and serve the acharyas, diligently seeking and cultivating the Bodhisattva Canon, doing all that they do, in brief up to offering them water bottles.
This is the fifth arousing of the mind of the bodhisattva.

Although born among humans, my nature will be stingy and I will be even more impoverished, perhaps becoming a slave, controlled and bound by others, like a lustful bird flying through the sky, going wherever it stays, frightened and perilous.

For this reason, they are unable to love and enjoy practicing giving and so forth.

I now give rise to this mind and draw close to good friends. I will obtain a human body and not begrudge my life and limbs.
